newsitem.title: JAPAN: JAPAN COMPUTER SHARES LIMP ON SLOWING DEMAND WORRY.
newsitem.headline: JAPAN COMPUTER SHARES LIMP ON SLOWING DEMAND WORRY.

text.p: Shares in Japanese computer firms limped in Thursday morning trade on the Tokyo bourse on worries that domestic computer demand may be waning, brokers said.
They said the anxieties overshadowed news overnight of a linkup between Microsoft Corp and Apple Computer Inc.
As of 0112 GMT Fujitsu Ltd was down 10 yen at 1,700 and NEC Corp was down 10 at 1,650. Toshiba Corp had fallen 14 yen to 731.

"About 70 percent of the Japanese personal computer market is dominated by Fujitsu, International Business Machines Corp and NEC, so the Apple and Microsoft tie-up is not seen as a threat," a broker at a medium-sized brokerage said.

U.S. technology issues rallied overnight in New York helped by news that Microsoft Corp was investing $150 million in Apple, which had racked up more that $1.6 billion in losses over the past 18 months.
"Investors are more worried about a slowdown in domestic computer demand," he said.

The Japan Electronic Industry Development Association said on Thursday that shipments of personal computers in the April-June period showed a rise of four percent from the same period last year to 1.7 million units.
In contrast, the PC shipments in the same period last year had shown a 51 percent increase year-on-year.
